verses.text: Antiochus, son of King Demetrius, sent a letter from the islands of the sea to Simon, the priest and leader of the Jews, and to all the nation.
verses.comment: Antiochus VII begins correspondence with the Jewish leader, Simon. His outreach demonstrates continued foreign interest and interference in Jewish affairs.

verses.text: The contents of the letter were as follows: 'King Antiochus to Simon, the high priest and friend of kings, and to the nation of the Jews, greeting.'
verses.comment: The formal greeting uses honorific titles, indicating Simon's elevated political and religious status. The relationship between foreign and Jewish leaders foreshadows later developments in judicial and religious authority.

verses.text: 'Because certain scoundrels have taken control of the kingdom of our ancestors, I wish to assert my rights and claim the throne, so that I may restore it, as it was before. I have therefore called back my armies and have decided to enter my own country.'
verses.comment: Antiochus frames his claim as rightful, highlighting the recurring motif of contested legitimacy in leadership—a theme echoed in salvation history.

verses.text: and intend to make a landing in the country so that I may proceed against those who have destroyed our country and those who have devastated many cities in my kingdom,
verses.comment: Antiochus VII (Sidetes) claims to act against those who harmed his kingdom, seeking to legitimize his military intervention in the region by blaming previous devastation, a common ancient political justification.

verses.text: now therefore I confirm to you all the tax remissions that the kings before me have granted you, and a release from all the other payments from which they have released you.
verses.comment: The confirmation of tax remissions continues a precedent of Hellenistic rulers seeking Jewish loyalty through religious and fiscal privileges, echoing similar grants by Antiochus III and Demetrius II (see 1 Macc 10:29-36).

verses.text: I permit you to mint your own coinage as money for your country,
verses.comment: Granting the right to mint coinage signifies recognition of Jewish autonomy under Simon, a significant step in self-governance and national identity.

verses.text: and I grant freedom to Jerusalem and the sanctuary. All the weapons that you have prepared and the strongholds that you have built and now hold shall remain yours.
verses.comment: This statement acknowledges Jerusalem's religious and political freedom, as well as Jewish retention of military resources, highlighting a new status among the Hellenistic powers.

verses.text: Every debt you owe to the royal treasury and any such future debts shall be canceled for you from henceforth and for all time.
verses.comment: Cancellation of past and future debts further strengthens Jewish economic independence and ingratiates Simon as a valuable ally.

verses.text: When we gain control of our kingdom, we will bestow great honor on you and your nation and the temple, so that your glory will become manifest in all the earth.”
verses.comment: Antiochus promises additional honor if victorious, illustrating how Hellenistic rulers incentivized local elites and affirming the Jewish community’s growing international reputation.

verses.text: In the one hundred seventy-fourth year Antiochus set out and invaded the land of his ancestors. All the troops rallied to him, so that there were only a few with Trypho.
verses.comment: The dating to the 174th year of the Seleucid era (138/137 BCE) situates Antiochus’ campaign against Trypho in a precise historical context, showing shifting allegiances and power struggles in the region.

verses.text: Antiochus pursued him, and Trypho came in his flight to Dor, which is by the sea;
verses.comment: Trypho's flight to Dor, a coastal stronghold, marks a desperate effort to evade capture after losing support—demonstrating the volatility of post-Antiochian succession.

verses.text: for he knew that troubles had converged on him, and his troops had deserted him.
verses.comment: Trypho’s isolation and loss of troops reflect rapid reversals of fortune in Hellenistic politics, emphasizing the importance of military loyalty.

verses.text: So Antiochus encamped against Dor, and with him were one hundred twenty thousand warriors and eight thousand cavalry.
verses.comment: The immense forces Antiochus brought against Dor illustrate the scale and seriousness of Seleucid civil wars and their destabilizing impact on the region.

verses.text: He surrounded the town, and the ships joined battle from the sea; he pressed the town hard from land and sea, and permitted no one to leave or enter it.
verses.comment: Simultaneous land and naval blockade presents a comprehensive siege, underscoring the strategic importance of Dor and the military capabilities of Antiochus.

verses.text: Then Numenius and his companions arrived from Rome, with letters to the kings and countries, in which the following was written:
verses.comment: The arrival of Jewish envoys from Rome signals the Maccabees’ diplomatic skill in cultivating foreign alliances to strengthen their autonomy.

verses.text: “Lucius, consul of the Romans, to King Ptolemy, greetings.
verses.comment: A letter from Lucius, a Roman consul, to Ptolemy, reflects Roman interest in eastern Mediterranean affairs and potential Jewish integration into Rome’s sphere of influence.

verses.text: The envoys of the Jews have come to us as our friends and allies to renew our ancient friendship and alliance. They had been sent by the high priest Simon and by the Jewish people
verses.comment: The high priest Simon uses diplomacy to solidify Jewish-Roman relations, seeking external support against regional threats, a recurring theme in Jewish history (see 1 Macc 8).

verses.text: and have brought a gold shield weighing one thousand minas.
verses.comment: Presentation of a gold shield as a diplomatic gift echoes ancient gift-exchange customs, symbolizing both respect and alliance.

verses.text: We therefore have decided to write to the kings and countries that they should not seek their harm or make war against them and their cities and their country, or make alliance with those who war against them.
verses.comment: Rome’s prohibition against hostilities or alliances targeting Jews demonstrates their emerging protective policy, possibly for their own strategic interests in the region.

verses.text: And it has seemed good to us to accept the shield from them.
verses.comment: The acceptance of the shield indicates Roman favor, suggesting political acknowledgment of the Jewish state’s significance.

verses.text: Therefore if any scoundrels have fled to you from their country, hand them over to the high priest Simon, so that he may punish them according to their law.”
verses.comment: The extradition clause affirms Jewish legal jurisdiction, strengthening Simon’s authority and the autonomy of the high priesthood.

verses.text: The consul wrote the same thing to King Demetrius and to Attalus and Ariarathes and Arsaces,
verses.comment: Identical letters sent throughout the Mediterranean display Rome’s diplomatic reach and intention to safeguard Jewish interests broadly.

verses.text: and to all the countries, and to Sampsames, and to the Spartans, and to Delos, and to Myndos, and to Sicyon, and to Caria, and to Samos, and to Pamphylia, and to Lycia, and to Halicarnassus, and to Rhodes, and to Phaselis, and to Cos, and to Side, and to Aradus and Gortyna and Cnidus and Cyprus and Cyrene.
verses.comment: The widespread distribution underscores the international recognition of Jewish claims and Rome’s intent to influence affairs across many polities.

verses.text: They also sent a copy of these things to the high priest Simon.
verses.comment: A copy sent to Simon emphasizes transparent communication and the high priest's central administrative role in the nascent Jewish polity.

verses.text: King Antiochus besieged Dor for the second time, continually throwing his forces against it and making engines of war; and he shut Trypho up and kept him from going out or in.
verses.comment: Antiochus’s renewed siege of Dor and the use of war machines foreground ongoing warfare, while Trypho’s entrapment signals his waning power.

verses.text: And Simon sent to Antiochus two thousand picked troops, to fight for him, and silver and gold and a large amount of military equipment.
verses.comment: Simon’s offer of troops and resources shows his willingness to ally with powerful neighbors for Jewish security, though the alliance proves precarious.

verses.text: But he refused to receive them, and broke all the agreements he formerly had made with Simon, and became estranged from him.
verses.comment: Antiochus’s rejection and broken promises reveal the fluidity and unreliability of Hellenistic diplomacy, leaving the Jews vulnerable despite prior agreements.

verses.text: He sent to him Athenobius, one of his Friends, to confer with him, saying, "You hold control of Joppa and Gazara and the citadel in Jerusalem; they are cities of my kingdom."
verses.comment: Antiochus, through Athenobius, accused the Jews of occupying royal Seleucid cities, highlighting ongoing disputes over legitimate boundaries and sovereignty.

verses.text: You have devastated their territory, you have done great damage in the land, and you have taken possession of many places in my kingdom.
verses.comment: The charge of devastation and conquest reflects Seleucid attempts to reassert control and delegitimize Jewish territorial gains.

verses.text: Now then, hand over the cities that you have seized and the tribute money of the places that you have conquered outside the borders of Judea;
verses.comment: Antiochus’ ultimatum—surrender or pay punitive tribute—demonstrates the economic and military pressures faced by the Jewish state amid regional power struggles.

verses.text: or else pay me five hundred talents of silver for the destruction that you have caused and five hundred talents more for the tribute money of the cities. Otherwise we will come and make war on you.”
verses.comment: The demands for indemnities and tribute emphasize the transactional nature of Hellenistic rule and regional dominance.

verses.text: So Athenobius, the king’s Friend, came to Jerusalem, and when he saw the splendor of Simon, and the sideboard with its gold and silver plate, and his great magnificence, he was amazed. When he reported to him the king’s message,
verses.comment: Athenobius’s awe at Simon’s wealth signals the Jewish leader’s status and the nation’s prosperity, while the delivery of the king’s terms reflects formal diplomatic engagement.

verses.text: Simon said to him in reply: "We have neither taken foreign land nor seized foreign property, but only the inheritance of our ancestors, which at one time had been unjustly taken by our enemies."
verses.comment: Simon’s reply asserts ancestral rights to the land, aligning the Maccabean struggle with the biblical inheritance motif (cf. Num 33:53; Deut 1:8), and reframing their actions as justified restoration.

verses.text: Now that we have the opportunity, we are firmly holding the inheritance of our ancestors.
verses.comment: Simon reinforces the legitimacy of Jewish possession, making a case for indigenous claims over foreign-imposed sovereignty.

verses.text: As for Joppa and Gazara, which you demand, they were causing great damage among the people and to our land; for them we will give you one hundred talents.” Athenobius did not answer him a word,
verses.comment: By offering a lesser tribute for Joppa and Gazara, Simon tries negotiation while refusing full Seleucid demands, reflecting his political pragmatism.

verses.text: but returned in wrath to the king and reported to him these words, and also the splendor of Simon and all that he had seen. And the king was very angry.
verses.comment: Athenobius’s silence and anger, together with the reported splendor, further inflame Antiochus, escalating tension and foreshadowing conflict.

verses.text: Meanwhile Trypho embarked on a ship and escaped to Orthosia.
verses.comment: Trypho’s maritime escape to Orthosia marks ongoing upheaval and the elusive fortunes of rival claimants in the region.

verses.text: Then the king made Cendebeus commander-in-chief of the coastal country, and gave him troops of infantry and cavalry.
verses.comment: Antiochus’s appointment of Cendebeus as a military leader highlights continued attempts to exert control over coastal and Jewish territories.

verses.text: He commanded him to encamp against Judea, to build up Kedron and fortify its gates, and to make war on the people; but the king pursued Trypho.
verses.comment: Orders to fortify Kedron and attack Judea underscore strategic efforts to contain and undermine Jewish strength amid Antiochus’s broader campaigns.

verses.text: So Cendebeus came to Jamnia and began to provoke the people and invade Judea and take the people captive and kill them.
verses.comment: Cendebeus’s invasion brings renewed harassment, captivity, and violence to Judean territory, reflecting persistent insecurity despite Simon’s leadership.

verses.text: He built up Kedron and stationed horsemen and troops there, so that they might go out and make raids along the highways of Judea, as the king had ordered him.
verses.comment: The fortification of Kedron and its use as a base for raids reveals ongoing threats to Jewish autonomy from entrenched Seleucid garrisons.
